awd_titl_txt: CRII: CHS: Examining a Multimodal Approach to Lowering the Burden of Food Journaling
awd_abstract_narration:
People use personal journaling methods to develop better habits and make informed decisions about health and well-being. Activities such as food journaling become burdensome, inaccurate, or incomplete over time due to poor design of supportive devices and single-platform constraints. In this project, the investigator plans to use internet-of-things (IoT) functionality to develop a system with integrated and multimodal input capabilities to support food journaling. An integrated device platform will be developed to support data input from multiple devices such as smart phones, wearables, and laptops. An iterative, user-centered design methodology will be applied. Prospective users will be selected for usability studies, and the prototype will be validated by comparing multimodal IoT-enabled food journaling to other common food journaling applications. Benefits include more usable technologies for personal journaling to support mental and physical health, stress management, and personal wellbeing. 

This project will center around two participatory design investigations. The research team (1) will examine how people with healthy eating goals use lightweight technology probes developed for journaling food via voice description, photography, or text description. This probe deployment will inform recommendations for how platforms can support collecting data collaboratively across input modalities. These recommendations, and an iterative design process to improve usability, will inform a full-featured multimodal food journaling tool. The research team (2) will then compare the developed tool against design strategies typical of commercial and research food journals, again with people who have healthy eating goals. The comparison will be mixed-methods, combining perceptions of the value and burden of the technology through validated survey instruments with semi-structured interviews discussing the challenges of each approach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Personal journaling methods such as food journaling have great potential to better help people understand themselves and their habits, but are notoriously burdensome to enact and continue using. Creating lower-burden, useful technologies for food journaling that people are willing and able to use in everyday life has the potential to help people better monitor diet monitoring goals from healthy eating, identifying food allergies and intolerances, and supporting chronic conditions like diabetes.

In this project, we took an internet-of-things (IoT) approach to supporting food journaling across devices and contexts that people use and experience everyday. The system we developed, ModEat, supported food journaling on smart speakers, smartwatches, mobile phones, and desktop and laptop computers. Further, it supported a range of methods of input like searching in a food database, scanning a barcode, taking a photo, and free text and voice description.

From having 15 people use ModEat for a few weeks, we learned that people's goals and personal circumstances impact what devices they use for journaling and what input techniques they use. For example, people who aim to become more aware of what they eat tended to use more open-ended inputs, like photos and free text, while people with diet monitoring goals tended to prefer inputs which let them monitor calories and nutrient information. The devices people used were influenced both by what was around and convenient in the moment, but also what data these devices could collect. Overall, we take away a need to better support journaling across devices and inputs, such as filling in initial details with a "quicker" input method and following up with more information at a later time.

Our work also pointed to valuable opportunities for improving how food journaling can be supported by new and emerging IoT technologies. In one project, we more closely examined how people might want to use voice-based smart speakers to journal, finding tensions between wanting the speaker to ask for more details about a food (like portion size) and wanting to journal quickly. In another project focused on automating the process of food journaling, we surfaced people find more familiar devices like smartwatches more acceptable and less socially awkward in practice, but that their detection capabilities are often lower than more invasive devices like sensors attached to the mouth or face.

Finally, our project has pointed out some important social factors which influence how useful people find food journaling with IoT devices. We find that often times, food journaling starts as a more personal goal, but later becomes informed by people's friends and social connections online. People's friends and families suggest what foods to eat and how to journal, which people then take back to their practice. Also, we find that food journaling practices largely vary by culture, with cultural perceptions on what's healthy or desirable influencing the design of food journaling apps and people's experiences with them.
